title: The Highway to Hell: America’s Interstate System as an Agent of Dampening Social Mobility
text:
This paper explores the potential consequences of residing near United States highways on social mobility, focusing on air pollution, job density, and absolute mobility. Investigating major cities within the U.S., the research employs a multiple regression analysis using the Opportunity Atlas and Social Capital data libraries to gauge the significance of highways in shaping mobility prospects. Findings reveal that highway proximity can hinder upward mobility due to factors like pollution exposure and limited resource access. Through this exploration, the paper sheds light on the multifaceted effects of highways, offering insights into their role in perpetuating socioeconomic disparities.
I worked on this study under the guidance of Prof. Bruich from the Harvard University Department of Economics, and in collaboration with Ruhama Baruda, Sarah Hassan, Angela Hilliard and Cady Ngo.
Products

Report
Poster

title: A Data Justice Project
text:
Data invisibility is a pressing societal issue, leaving certain groups excluded and misrepresented, which distorts our social understanding and perpetuates stereotypes. The lack of transgender representation in official datasets is a clear example of this, impacting policies and societal perceptions. Despite efforts for data justice, transgender data remains scarce in surveys, limiting our grasp of LGBTQI+ experiences.
In my project, I tackle two primary research questions:
- What are the key challenges and considerations in accurately representing transgender individuals within official datasets?
- What is the current state of data representation efforts on the transgender population, who is driving these initiatives, and why are they significant?
I conducted qualitative research, delving into literature reviews and using RStudio for data analysis on SOGI-related collection in federal surveys.
The findings shed light on three critical hurdles in collecting transgender data: limitations in self-identification methods, privacy concerns, and the need to build trust. Surveys’ fixed categories often fail to capture the fluidity of gender identity, and privacy risks loom large amidst changing legislation impacting LGBTQ rights. Addressing these issues requires more inclusive methods, like write-in responses, alongside stringent privacy safeguards and community collaborations to foster trust.
Driving these data collection efforts are civil-society organizations and academia, leading responsible initiatives for gender minorities. Comprehensive SOGI data is indispensable for understanding disparities, enhancing well-being, and crafting evidence-based policies.
Next steps for this project include incorporating the findings from the study into the report being developed for the Center for Global Health Equity at the University of Virginia. Additionally, accessing and exploring wider data sources is key to expanding the findings of this study, hoping that it will contribute to global conversation about SOGI data collection and responsible data science.

Poster

title: Predicting Life Expectancy: The Effect of Economic Indicators
text:
In this study, my aim was to delve into the intricate relationship between economic indicators and life expectancy, questioning the adequacy of conventional country classifications. Life Expectancy (LE) isn’t just a measure of healthcare quality; it’s a multifaceted indicator reflecting a nation’s economic, social, and environmental status.
Using WHO and UN data, I discovered a positive correlation between a country’s Income Composition of Resources (ICOR) and life expectancy. Even a small increase in ICOR was associated with a notable rise in life expectancy, challenging the simplistic “developed” versus “developing” country categories.
This study highlights the limitations of relying solely on economic indicators. While developed nations generally exhibit higher life expectancies, some developing countries effectively utilize resources to surpass global life expectancy averages.
It emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach, integrating social, cultural, and political factors alongside economic indicators to grasp life expectancy determinants fully. This work opens pathways for future exploration, urging a broader analysis of non-economic influences and resource utilization for a deeper understanding of global life expectancy dynamics.
Products

Report

title: Predicting AirBnb Prices in NYC
text:
In the heart of the bustling metropolis that is New York City, a dynamic marketplace of AirBnb listings unfolds, offering a plethora of accommodations to travelers from all corners of the globe. From snug apartments in the heart of Manhattan to expansive lofts in Brooklyn, these listings not only span the spectrum in terms of location but also come with a rich array of features and amenities. I embark on a statistical exploration to uncover the underlying factors that dictate the price of these listings. This study revolved around two pivotal questions:

Predicting Airbnb Listing Prices: Can we forecast the price of an AirBnb listing based on its features?
The Anatomy of Price Differences: What are the discerning characteristics that elevate some listings to a higher price bracket than others?

Products

Report

title: Airbnb Insights: a Visual Analysis
text:
From Data To Destinations: Visual Analysis of European Airbnbs  In this data science Research Project project we aimed to study study European Airbnb Listings using a sample of 10 major cities. For this purpose, we created a Shiny App that allows the user to interact with a series of data visualizations that explore what are the factors correlated with price and guest satisfaction in European Airbnb listings.
 For further research, I am working on developing a model than can predict the prices for new listing (out of sample data) based on the features inputted by the user.
 About the Data  Data collection occurred approximately four to six weeks before the planned travel dates. Moreover, the collected prices encompass the total amount required for the accommodation, inclusive of reservation fees and cleaning fees for two nights.  Source: Khemani, D. (2023, March 25). Airbnb cleaned Europe dataset. Kaggle. Source: Khemani, D. (2023, March 25). Airbnb cleaned Europe dataset. Kaggle.

title: María C. Sánchez Linares
text:
About me
I am data science and economics student largely interested in solving social and economic problems with data-based solution. I have coursework Data Analysis and Visualization, Machine Learning, Statistical Modeling, Environmental and Economic Policy. I have a foundation in data-driven research and am looking for opportunities to get hands-on work experience. I have a passion for social justice, and blending my expertise, I aim to leverage data to inform innovative solutions to real-world challenges in the business and policy-making realms.

title: María C. Sánchez Linares
text:
Personal
I was born and raised in Valencia, Venezuela. At the age of 18, I received a United World College scholarship to attend UWC Red Cross Nordic in Flekke, Norway. After finishing the International Baccalaureate diploma, I moved to Saint Paul, MN to start my undergraduate studies at Macalester College.
I find joy in embracing new adventures and experiences. I am not your typical outdoors enthusiast, but I like skiing and kayaking. I also enjoy exploring new flavors through food touring and baking.
Most recently, I am preparing for my next journey. I have always loved traveling, and I am excited to be studying abroad in Málaga, Spain come spring 2024.
